ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- Basic overview of linear algebra concepts ranging from matrix arithmetic to orthogonality
- Basic overview of multivariable calculus concepts ranging from partial derivatives to optimization
- How the above subjects relate to applied data analysis and econometric problems
Learned introductory multivariable calculus and linear algebra.
I learned a lot about linear algebra and some basic multivariable calculus
A grasp of some of the fundamental concepts of linear algebra and multivariable calculus. Helped my work ethic with two psets and quizzes per week.
Matrix manipulation, LU Factorization, Vectors, Partial Derivatives, Lagrange multipliers: a strong introduction for linear algebra and multivariable calculus
Mostly linear algebra, some multivariate calculus.

Knowledge about Linear Algebra and Multivariable Calculus. 
I learned to enjoy doing math as well.
Good preview into the kind of math that is useful for work in economics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: covered a wide range of concepts with many examples provided
weaknesses: final unit was a bit rushed

Strengths: covers a lot of material in a short time. Prof. Jia is generous with her time and caring. Grading and assignments are fair.

Weaknesses: covering a lot of material in a short time, compounded with this being an accelerated summer course, made it very, very difficult. The speed of the course was breakneck. Although I have a feeling this was just because this was taught in the summer.

The course was very fast-paced, and sometimes it was a bit hard to process all the information. Perhaps it would have been helpful to do three two-hour sessions a week instead of two three-hour sessions. I also wish Prof Jia had provided us with an answer key after each assignment/quiz was graded.
It is very condensed - perhaps the material from the last and penultimate class can be switched so the hardest stuff is covered well before the final.

Weaknesses: the quizzes being done every class was an inefficient way, in my view of assessing the students. I feel like the midterm, final exam format would be much better. It's hard to be assessed on material that we've only learned a couple days ago. 

Strengths: I definitely feel that this class shouldn't be a class taught in the summer, given just the how extensive the material is. But I believe Prof. Jia did a great job holding office hours and taking breaks, really catering students' needs when it came to understanding the material being taught in class and overall academic performance.
I enjoy the class very much. Dr. Ning Jia is a very good professor.

Strengths:
- Professor was helpful and good at communicating information
- Office hours were useful

Weaknesses:
- Homework assignments were often quite lengthy
- Material on the quizzes was sometimes not what was on the homework, even though that was what we were told to expect.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this to anyone who is looking to pursue economics or data analysis
Yes, but be prepared to work your butt off.
Yes if they haven't taken math since high school and want to get back into it.
I would if they are pursuing a career in this field and need a fundamental understanding of linear algebra and multivariable calculus.

Only if you want to learn more linear algebra. I've taken all of the economics prerequisites, the only thing from this class that came up there were the Lagrange equations, although those can be tricky.
Yes. The course taught in a quick pace and covered a lot of useful materials. The professor is patient and understanding. The office hours are readily available.
Yes, but only if the student has the time to dedicate to it since it was very intensive.
